positive.review: An extraction shooter with short rounds, PVE that needs to be managed and PVP which is super intense. No excessive looting or elaborate crafting that needs to be done. I love this game, there's nothing like it. Super atmosphere and great gunplay. See you in the bayou, cowboys.

One of the better extraction shooters currently available. The unique horror / western setting and the gunplay attached to this is what really sets it apart from the rest. Gunfights in this game tend to be a lot more methodical and slower-paced, with a huge emphasis on good positioning and covering angles in order to land one well-placed shot. 

The sound design is also top-notch, all the way from in-game assets to the music playing in the menu. The sounds also offer important gameplay cues during gameplay, which further immerses you in the experience. 

It should be noted, however, that while this game pegs itself as "PvPvE", the emphasis of the gameplay leans heavily into PvP. Any PVE-encounters in the game ultimately serve as vectors for PVP-combat. It used to skew differently in the past (pre-Scrapbeak), which is probably what caused the skewed perception in this aspect of the game, but I would say this is primarily a PVP-game with light PvE-elements. 

The structure of the game is also more objective-based than other extraction shooters in this game. The game goes to great lengths to signpost you towards your next "goal", which is usually hunting for bounty tokens. This generally solves a huge issue which tends to plauge extraction games, which is the lack of direction these games elicit, due to their generally Sandboxy-nature of gameplay.  

You can still extract out at any time during a match, regardless of that rounds current gamestate, which is one of the key features in extraction games. Due to the open vast and open nature of the maps in Hunt, there is some room for "Sandbox" style-gameplay, especially during their special events that they've held during the recent years.  

The economy, which is another key feature in these games, is also vastly simplified compared to other games in the genre. Yes, you lose everything you carry if you die, but it is also very easy to gain it back, as the game gives you multiple avenues of collecting gear without having to break your ingame bank for it. The loadouts in this game also tend to be very simple to put together, as you can only carry a very limited numbers of items with each loadout. In the end, this simplified loadout / inventory system benefits the game, as it makes getting into a new match very quick.

There is also no player-driven market in the game, which means you don't have to deal with fluctuating loadout values. Everything that your character needs can either be purchased from the in-game vendor or gathered while playing the game. 

Overall, if you're looking for a more unique PVP(VE)-experience that isn't as rigid as say, Counter-Strike, Hunt offers a very compelling experience that differs from the usual PVP shooter-offerings.

Hunt: Showdown 1896 — Where Hope Goes to Die (But in a Fun Way)
Hunt: Showdown 1896 is the perfect game for anyone who ever thought, *“You know what would improve my day? Dying in a swamp to a stranger with a rusty shotgun.”*
Every match starts with dreams of glory and treasure… and ends with you staring at the respawn screen while some cowboy loots your body like it’s Black Friday.
The sound design? Terrifyingly good. I now flinch at crows, creaking wood, and my own footsteps.
The atmosphere? So thick you could butter toast with it.
The gameplay? A beautiful mix of PvPvE chaos where your biggest enemy is usually your own panic.
But when it *works* — when you grab the bounty, escape the map, and feel like a legendary monster slayer instead of a walking donation — that’s the magic that keeps everyone coming back.

Verdict:

10/10 — Will happily return to the swamp, fully aware I won’t last longer than my morning coffee.

Hunt is my favourite game, and nothing else really scratches the same itch. It’s a tough, tense PvPvE shooter where you play as a bounty hunter tracking and killing a target in a cursed bayou while other hunters try to stop you. You gather clues, kill and banish the boss, then fight your way out with the bounty, all while every sound you make can give away your position.

The risk reward loop is incredibly satisfying. Almost everything you do earns cash for future loadouts, but anything you die with is gone for good. Surviving hunters earn traits that make them slightly stronger for the next match. It sounds like a snowball system, but it isn’t: every weapon has strengths, and even the starter gear is competitive if you play to its advantages. Skill and game knowledge matter far more than equipment.

The real hurdle for new players is the learning curve. The maps are dense with details, sound traps, angles, and interactions you just have to learn. You’ll die a lot at first—often without understanding how. But once you get past that, the game becomes uniquely thrilling. Nothing beats coordinating with a partner to outsmart and outplay another team.

The devs are another major positive: they’re active, responsive, and constantly adding new content. I’ve bought plenty of cosmetic DLC just to support them.

No matter what other shooters I try, I keep coming back to Hunt and probably always will, as long as there are hunters left to fight.

Nevertheless, I can recommend it for both solo and team players.

A Once-in-a-Generation Experience - Still Finding Its Way Back

I loved Hunt: Showdown before the 2.0 update.
I was genuinely hyped for everything that was promised… and then the update hit.
A catastrophe followed.

The game has been struggling ever since the engine upgrade. Performance issues, strange design choices, a loss of identity -> Hunt went through a rough phase that many long-time players felt deeply. But today, after several patches and improvements, the game is slowly recovering. It’s not fully back on its feet, but it’s finally starting to feel like Hunt again: creeping back into the very specific niche where it belongs, and where it truly shines.

Still, I fear we may never get the old Hunt back. Corporate influence has clearly tightened its grip. 

just look at the rapid release cycle of paid DLCs and in-game microtransactions. There is a stain on the experience that the game can’t completely shake off.

What Made Hunt Special

Hunt: Showdown was never meant to be a run-and-gun shooter like Call of Duty.
It was never designed to be fast-food FPS entertainment.

Hunt rewarded something else entirely:

Map knowledge

Stealth, patience, and positioning

Reading sound cues and predicting enemy behavior

Timing, risk assessment, and tactical decision-making

It was, unapologetically, a hardcore game.
A game that did not bend over backwards to be accessible to everyone.
A game that embraced tension, punishments for mistakes, and high stakes.
A game where every bullet counted and every noise betrayed you.

This is what made Hunt unique - and why so many players fell in love with it.

Where We Stand Now

The fun is back. The tension is back. The core of Hunt still exists beneath all the turbulence.
But the past hangs over it. The identity has shifted, and some of the purity is gone.

Still, after all these years and all these changes, Hunt: Showdown remains an experience you won’t find anywhere else: atmospheric, brutal, tactical, and unforgettable.

If Crytek continues to steer the game back toward what made it exceptional, Hunt may yet reclaim its full potential.
For now, it’s imperfect, but still one of the most unique shooters ever made.
If the candle is burning, it means dinner has been prepared for a long time.

There's really nothing quite like Hunt, one of the best online gameplay loops available today. Hunt is an PvPvE extraction shooter based in the late 1800s in the American South with a somewhat Resident Evil-style aesthetic. This game is about strategic skill as much as it is about technical skill. Your primary task is to locate and eliminate Boss NPCs and collect their bounty tokens and successfully extract; where this becomes more complicated is when you realize every other player on the map has the same goal. You'll need to be alert at all times and use environmental cues to track/avoid other players positions. Custom loadout options allow for various builds and playstyles, just don't get too attached to your hunters due to permadeath.

Overall, I highly recommend this game. The Hunt giveth and the Hunt taketh.

The only FPS that I consistently keep coming back to thanks to its gripping atmosphere and tense gunfights. Six years later and the game is still updated with new content and unique events that change the world and introduce new mechanics.

Unlike other extraction shooters, this isn't an inventory simulator, so you spend much more time actually playing, although much of it is just walking between compounds to get clues that lead you to the boss. Similarly, gear fear isn't as bad here, though you can't sell anything that you've picked up in the world so there's less reward for looting and extracting.

The best part of the game are the gunfights. Although most guns one-shot to the head, and may only require two or three to the chest, guns tend to be slow firing so firefights can be long and drawn out, which makes for rewarding gameplay if you win them.

Performance does leave some to be desired, but is usually serviceable enough - I average around 80-120fps on an (admittedly now 7 year old but only 1 year old when the game released) RTX 2080 and I7-9700K with 24GB of RAM at 1440p on the lowest settings.

[h3]9/10[/h3]

The game is simply amazing. I highly recommend it.

It is pretty easy to understand what you have to do from the tutorial, but it gets complicated quickly when you have to take in consideration all the little details, like noise, terrain and which way to approach a situation. Your patience and strategy will also be tested a lot.

The game usually has a slow build until the battles begin, but the tension is very high. Any mistake may get you killed if you are not paying attention. It is also very rewarding when you win a team/solo battle, the adrenaline rush after a lot of tension feels very good.

I love this game so far and I think for someone who never played it but likes shooters it is worth a try.

(European experience based review)
Short review: Uniquely styled PvPvE Objective Extraction Shooter that hits a niche spot. It has one of the best PvP I've had so far and a steep learning curve. Highly recommended.

Longer review: Since first launching the game until a bit of mastering of the core mechanics and the flow of the game, the game was visually pleasing. From dark death-themed lore to every encounter with the AI and environment, it was a lot of fun. 

I saw the rise, the controversies and the so-called fall(s), bugs that were there since day 1 that still aren't addressed, the UI shipwreck and all of its versions, and of course new (sometimes game breaking) bugs with each update, it all stepped aside to the PvP side of this game since it was that good. 

It all sounds minimal, and you'd be right... until I mention that the game has 2 major issues as well and 1 that pairs with them. More precisely, this game has a swarm of ping abusers and bad servers in general. Let me go over the major latter first:

Issue n1: Bad servers. I lived and played this game mostly from Croatia, yet my ping is better on Russian servers than it is on European servers. If you get a single hiccup with the internet connection, the game will kick you out and beat you to the ground. There exists a reconnect button, which is a bigger gamble for the success of its functionality than betting on the green 00 - ten times in a row and winning every time. Even if you are reconnected, you see the environment, just the bare field and you can't play at all, ultimately teasing you, so you gotta try your luck with reconnect, again. It got so bad to the point that I had to pay for a VPN access to play the game on European servers, mind you, Croatia is in Europe.

Issue n2: Ping abusing. This is a wonderful orchestra. You have 1 huge server, which shall not be named, that has more cheaters than regular players and you can go to their own webshop and buy a hardware cheatsso they just gotta connect it and voila; cheats. It got so bad that the regular players have to switch to another server (+ they got higher ping thus ping abuse and are thus more successful in their games), this immigration led the local players of that server to switch to european servers, and the entire cycle continues. Being hit and dying, while behind cover with a bullet that cannot penetrate any surfaces, is just exhausting after a while.

I won't mention cheaters as an issue, since, let's face it, gaming companies are NOT about moral, but about business, and games will always have cheaters of some form or another. 

Somewhat of an major issue: MMR. Like any other game, this game has players of all kinds of skills and the gameplay changes based on them. Hunt has its own MMR and it is "stars", with lowest being 1 and highest being 6. I've been a 6star for so long that even a week of very long gaming sessions of constant dying didn't bring it down to 5 stars. The gunplay and gameplay at 6star is ridiculus. Everyone is jumping every other second so you not only need to take in the consideration of the velocity of the bullet, the trajectory, its silly "gravity", but also the erratic mid-air-direction-changing all you can jump buffet where wanna be alpha-giga-chads can't let anyone hit them in the head. Now try combining this with the 2nd issue of the review and try to work who would win in a fight like that. Mind you, hit-reg is wanky at times so bullets sometimes just go through their body in to the abyss.

All this being said: the game is pretty good. You have a variety of guns 'n' tools 'n' consumables. Only your imagination is your limit. Although, more general loadouts dominate higher MMRs, and I always went out of my way to avoid the Mosin+Dolch combo for example. I find fun in their confusion of their playstyle when they go against something that isn't often seen.

They are adding more and more content, from guns, tools and consumables to new events. Man, the events... as of now, an event is when there are NO events. One after another, (obtain premium currency to) unlock the premium side of the event-rewards (mostly skins and miscelaneous item-animations) and grind it. No event is same, since they are always experimenting and navigating the game through data-driven decisions.

Highly recommended for PvP and also PvE side, since that is a "mental melody" of sequences that you can visually see and play out. From juking and killing a pack of Hellhounds with the knuckle knife without getting bitten not even once, to juking Grunts and navigating a compound full of AI while killing in front of you and juking behind you, at this point it's a mental stimulation of its own.

Already long review and I'll stop while I can (and want to, at this point). 
Bottom line is: game and gameplay loop and gunplay is good, but it's better if you can convince a buddy or two to get it as well (tho solo experience in the game ties to your skills, you can still do it and you have additional perk advantages). Game won't feel boring after a while, since every event brings a shift. Be it tiny or huge, it makes the game as fresh as it can and it nicely combines with the god-tier PvP.

An objective extraction shooter. Focus on the OBJECTIVE part of extraction shooter, Loot is almost non existent, and the focus is pvp where everyone dies to a single well placed headshot. 

For the uninitiated this game starts you on a map with 11 other players and you are all looking for the same bounty target. The target is a pve enemy that you kill, "banish" (meaning start a timer that alerts the entire map where the bounty is), once the banish is complete you can grab the bounty and try to extract.

Since everyone has the same target(s) this inevitably leads to pvp. Which is where the game shines. Almost all of the guns have a relatively slow rate of fire. Meaning you have take time and place your shots because you don't know if the enemy will take cover before you can fire a second shot. Put on top of that the fact that everyone can die in a single headshot and you got yourself some tense pvp!

This also mitigates one issue I have with other extraction shooters which is that higher geared players are harder to kill that low gear players. Which feels leads to severely unbalanced fights at times.

This isn't to say that Hunt doesn't have gear however. You can out spend your opponents with statistically better weapons (higher bullet velocity, slightly more damage on body shots, faster but not too fast cycling time) but at the end of the day if some hits a clean headshot you're dead like the rest.

Another aspect of this game that no other can touch is the audio design. I don't know how they did it, but the audio in this game is the best in the business. You can tell where everyone is just by the sounds of their footsteps and if you listen carefully. Combine this with the fact that the main purpose of the pve enemies is to act as sound queues to give away your positions and even the pve makes for a decent "avoid the audio queues" mini game.

Finally the last aspect of the game that keeps me coming back and that is this. No other game has had me say "Wow I've never had a fight like that" with 1300 hours of playtime. I consistent end up in wildly different gunfights almost every time I boot up the game.

If that doesn't say something. I don't know what does.

My favorite game in a while, can't remember the last time I've been so hooked on a game. Played it like a second job, and at 500 hours I felt I was just starting to understand the game and mechanics. I am now writing this at 1000 hours because I feel I have a valid experience of Hunt. I float around 5 star never really 6 star, I don't think I'm any good at the game but I think game knowledge itself has helped me play better. I didn't enjoy the game at 30 hours because there was lots of unfamiliarity but at about 200 I really fell in love. It's an intense hardcore shooter, rewards great discipline with aiming as well as positioning, great gun play with 1-shot headshots, some creative utility uses when in a pinch or to set up, and not your typical loot fest so lots more action. Of course there are some draw backs, as with any live service game, wonky servers, unbalanced patches, broken mechanics, but I feel the experience Hunt Showdown offers triumphs all that, if anything adds to the chaotic nature of the game at times. PvE is just meh but the design of mobs and atmosphere of the maps are unbeatable, just sometimes feels like a chore but I think that's as intended to slow down the game. Music and sound design is also 10/10.

TL:DR game good, can be hard to pick up, but if you like hardcore shooters it is a must try
